elements.content: A fluorine-modified tetracarboxylic acid ligand, namely, 2′-fluoro-[1,1′:4′,1′′-terphenyl]-3,3′′,5,5′′-tetracarboxylic acid (H4FTPTC), with suitable triplet energy excited state, was designed and applied to construct the luminescent lanthanide metal–organic frameworks (LnMOFs) for cryogenic temperature sensing. With the lanthanides codoping strategy, we developed a new Tb3+/Eu3+ mixed LnMOF system Tb 1–x Eu x FTPTC (x = 0.05, 0.1, 0.2), which feature excellent linear responses to temperature with high relative sensitivity in the cryogenic range of 25–125 K. It was found that the relative sensitivity of such mixed LnMOF could readily be tuned by adjusting the incorporation amount of Eu3+ ions in the host framework. In addition, the energy transfer efficiency between the Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions in the framework with different Tb3+/Eu3+ ratios are also investigated and discussed.

With the lanthanides codoping strategy, we developed a new Tb3+/Eu3+ mixed LnMOF system Tb  1-x   Eu   x   FTPTC (x = 0.05, 0.1, 0.2), which feature excellent linear responses to temperature with high relative sensitivity in the cryogenic range of 25-125 K. It was found that the relative sensitivity of such mixed LnMOF could readily be tuned by adjusting the incorporation amount of Eu3+ ions in the host framework. In addition, the energy transfer efficiency between the Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions in the framework with different Tb3+/Eu3+ ratios are also investigated and discussed.

elements.content: A fluorine-modified organic linker 2′-fluoro-[1,1′:4′,1′′-terphenyl]-3,3′′,5,5′′-tetracarboxylic acid was first synthesized and applied for constructing luminescent mixed lanthanide MOFs Tb 1−x Eu x FTPTC (x = 0.05, 0.1, 0.2). The latter exhibits excellent temperature-dependent photoluminescence properties with high relative sensitivity in the temperature range of 25−125 K, which could be useful for accurate temperature sensing in the cryogenic regime.

elements.content: Fast and accurate determination of cryogenic temperature is crucial across a wide range of areas, including basic science, engineering, manufacturing, metallurgy, aerospace, and so on. With the rapid development of modern technology, many thermal-sensitive materials, such as platinum RTDs, special thermistors, and silicon diodes, have been developed for use as cryogenic temperature sensing and control elements. However, these commonly used sensors have a large size and must be in physical contact with the object being sensed, which is not suitable for remote temperature detection of large-area thermal distributions, fast-moving objects, or at micro-and nanoscales. In addition, their electrical link modules impede their application in strong magnetic and/or radio frequency fields. Luminescence-based ratiometric techniques can overcome these drawbacks and provide a very promising alternative for precise temperature measurements due to its self-calibrating, as well as noninvasiveness, observability, high spatial resolution, and sensitivity properties. In the past decade, numerous luminescent materials have been explored to construct the novel ratiometric thermometers. These include semiconducting polymer dots, molecular lanthanide coordination compounds, Er3+/Yb3+ codoped nanoparticles, host–guest composites, and lanthanide metal–organic frameworks (LnMOFs).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Fast and accurate determination of cryogenic temperature is crucial across a wide range of areas, including basic science, engineering, manufacturing, metallurgy, aerospace, and so on. With the rapid development of modern technology, many thermal-sensitive materials, such as platinum RTDs, special thermistors, and silicon diodes, have been developed for use as cryogenic temperature sensing and control elements. However, these commonly used sensors have a large size and must be in physical contact with the object being sensed, which is not suitable for remote temperature detection of large-area thermal distributions, fast-moving objects, or at micro-and nanoscales. In addition, their electrical link modules impede their application in strong magnetic and/or radio frequency fields. Luminescence-based ratiometric techniques can overcome these drawbacks and provide a very promising alternative for precise temperature measurements due to its self-calibrating, as well as noninvasiveness, observability, high spatial resolution, and sensitivity properties. In the past decade, numerous luminescent materials have been explored to construct the novel ratiometric thermometers. These include semiconducting polymer dots, molecular lanthanide coordination compounds, Er3+/Yb3+ codoped nanoparticles, host-guest composites, and lanthanide metal-organic frameworks (LnMOFs).

elements.content: LnMOFs, assembled in an orderly manner from lanthanide ions or clusters with organic ligands, are especially useful for engineering the luminescence properties because of the intrinsic advantages of the porous MOFs and the spectroscopic properties of the lanthanides. They are versatile multifunctional luminescent materials and have been investigated for a wide range of sensing applications, especially in temperature measurement. In the multicenter LnMOFs, the luminescence of different lanthanide ions depends strongly on the temperature. Thus, the ratio between the luminescence intensities of two different centers can be employed to realize self-calibrating luminescent thermometers of high accuracy and fast response. With the lanthanides codoping strategy, Qian et al. developed the first ratiometric luminescent Tb3+/Eu3+-MOF thermometer using the Tb3+/Eu3+ emission ratio as the thermometric parameter, namely, the Eu 0.0069 Tb 0.9931 -DMBDC (DMBDC = 2,5-dimethoxy-1,4-benzendicarboxylate), which features an operating range of 50–200 K and a maximum relative sensitivity of 1.15% K–1 at 200 K. Since then, based on the same principle, a number of Tb/Eu-MOFs have been realized that deliver good performance in the temperature range of 10–300 K. Although several excellent Tb/Eu-MOF thermometers for the cryogenic regime have been developed in the past 5 years, it is still a great challenge to fabricate Tb/Eu-MOFs with higher sensitivity. More importantly, effective control and modulation of the energy transfer process in the Tb/Eu-MOF thermometers, mainly involving ligand-to-Tb3+, ligand-to-Eu3+, and Tb3+-to-Eu3+, are critical for the sensing properties.

They are versatile multifunctional luminescent materials and have been investigated for a wide range of sensing applications, especially in temperature measurement. In the multicenter LnMOFs, the luminescence of different lanthanide ions depends strongly on the temperature. Thus, the ratio between the luminescence intensities of two different centers can be employed to realize self-calibrating luminescent thermometers of high accuracy and fast response. With the lanthanides codoping strategy, Qian et al. developed the first ratiometric luminescent Tb3+/Eu3+-MOF thermometer using the Tb3+/Eu3+ emission ratio as the thermometric parameter, namely, the Eu  0.0069  Tb  0.9931  -DMBDC (DMBDC = 2,5-dimethoxy-1,4-benzendicarboxylate), which features an operating range of 50-200 K and a maximum relative sensitivity of 1.15% K-1 at 200 K. Since then, based on the same principle, a number of Tb/Eu-MOFs have been realized that deliver good performance in the temperature range of 10-300 K. Although several excellent Tb/Eu-MOF thermometers for the cryogenic regime have been developed in the past 5 years, it is still a great challenge to fabricate Tb/Eu-MOFs with higher sensitivity. More importantly, effective control and modulation of the energy transfer process in the Tb/Eu-MOF thermometers, mainly involving ligand-to-Tb3+, ligand-to-Eu3+, and Tb3+-to-Eu3+, are critical for the sensing properties.

elements.content: Organic ligands with suitable triplet lowest energy excited state (T1), generally in the range of 22 000–27 000 cm–1, have proved to be capable of sensitizing the Tb3+ and Eu3+ luminescence in the Tb/Eu-MOFs simultaneously. Concerning cryogenic thermometers based on the luminescent Tb/Eu-MOFs, the energy difference between the ligand’s T1 and Tb3+ accepting level should be controlled in a small range in order to ensure that the Tb3+ luminescence is sensitive to cryogenic temperatures, which is a prerequisite for tuning the temperature response of the luminescence intensity ratio between Tb3+ and Eu3+ in the cryogenic region (<100 K). In addition, a uniform distribution and suitable spatial distance of the f–f centers are believed to facilitate the energy transfer from the Tb3+ to Eu3+ ions. Accordingly, we have designed and synthesized a new fluorine-modified tetracarboxylic acid ligand, 2′-fluoro-[1,1′:4′,1′′-terphenyl]-3,3′′,5,5′′-tetracarboxylic acid (H4FTPTC), as the organic linker to construct the new Tb/Eu-MOFs for cryogenic temperature sensing. Note that modification of [1,1′:4′,1′′-terphenyl]-3,3′′,5,5′′-tetracarboxylic acid with fluorine atom can affect the distribution of the energy levels of the organic ligands, and make the ligand’s T1 close to the accepting level of Tb3+, satisfying the requirement of Tb/Eu-MOFs for cryogenic temperature sensing. On the basis of first principle calculations, the T1 energy of H4FTPTC was determined to be 24 037 cm–1, which shows a small gap of 3537 cm–1 higher than the accepting level of Tb3+, indicating the Tb3+ luminescence would be strongly decreased with temperature increase due to enhanced thermal activation of the nonradiative decays. In addition, the symmetric distribution of carboxyl groups and the large backbone of the H4FTPTC allow the construction of high-dimensional frameworks with orderly arranged f–f centers, which can facilitate the energy transfer from Tb3+ to Eu3+ ions. As expected, the 3D LnMOFs Tb 1–x Eu x FTPTC (x = 0.05, 0.1, 0.2) were successfully prepared under solvothermal conditions, and their thermometric parameters featuring excellent linear response to temperature for 25–125 K, with high relative sensitivity. In addition, the energy transfer efficiency between the Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions in the framework with different Tb3+/Eu3+ ratios are also investigated and discussed.

elements.content: Unless otherwise noted, all the chemicals and materials were obtained from commercial resources and used as received without additional purification. The 1H NMR spectra of the organic compounds were conducted on a Bruker Advance DMX 500 spectrometer. The 13C NMR spectrum of the H4FTPTC was obtained using a Bruker Ultrashield 400 Plus. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was measured on a Netzsch TG209F3 analyzer in nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C per minute. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were carried out on an MAXima_X XRD-7000 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.542 Å) and collected in the 2θ range of 3–50° at room condition. The lanthanide molar ratios in the mixed LnMOFs were determined by inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectroscopy (IRIS Intrepid II XSP, Thermo). Elemental analysis of the compounds were conducted with an EA1112 microelemental analyzer. The temperature-dependent luminescence measurements were carried out using an Edinburgh F920 spectrometer equipped with a He closed-cycle cryostat system with a Lakeshore 331 temperature controller, and the slits for the emission and excitation are fixed at 1 nm. The quantum yield measurements for the LnMOFs were performed on an Edinburgh F920 fluorescence spectrometer using an integrating sphere coated with BaSO4 (Inner diameter: 150 mm) and determined by an absolute method. Single-crystal XRD measurement was conducted at room temperature on a Bruker SMART APEX II diffractometer using a graphite-monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Bruker SAINT Program was used for determining the unit cell and collecting diffraction data of TbFTPTC. The crystal structure of TbFTPTC was obtained by direct methods using SHELXTL and then refined using the SHELX-2013 program based on the full-matrix least-squares method. Final crystallographic data of the TbFTPTC are listed in Table S1.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Measurements

Unless otherwise noted, all the chemicals and materials were obtained from commercial resources and used as received without additional purification. The 1H NMR spectra of the organic compounds were conducted on a Bruker Advance DMX 500 spectrometer. The 13C NMR spectrum of the H4FTPTC was obtained using a Bruker Ultrashield 400 Plus. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was measured on a Netzsch TG209F3 analyzer in nitrogen atmosphere with a heating rate of 5 °C per minute. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were carried out on an MAXima_X XRD-7000 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.542 Å) and collected in the 2θ range of 3-50° at room condition. The lanthanide molar ratios in the mixed LnMOFs were determined by inductively coupled plasma (ICP) spectroscopy (IRIS Intrepid II XSP, Thermo). Elemental analysis of the compounds were conducted with an EA1112 microelemental analyzer. The temperature-dependent luminescence measurements were carried out using an Edinburgh F920 spectrometer equipped with a He closed-cycle cryostat system with a Lakeshore 331 temperature controller, and the slits for the emission and excitation are fixed at 1 nm. The quantum yield measurements for the LnMOFs were performed on an Edinburgh F920 fluorescence spectrometer using an integrating sphere coated with BaSO4 (Inner diameter: 150 mm) and determined by an absolute method. Single-crystal XRD measurement was conducted at room temperature on a Bruker SMART APEX II diffractometer using a graphite-monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Bruker SAINT Program was used for determining the unit cell and collecting diffraction data of TbFTPTC. The crystal structure of TbFTPTC was obtained by direct methods using SHELXTL and then refined using the SHELX-2013 program based on the full-matrix least-squares method. Final crystallographic data of the TbFTPTC are listed in Table S1.

elements.content: To a mixture of 1,4-dibromo-2-fluorobenzene (2.54 g, 10 mmol), dimethyl 5-(4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-1,3,2-dioxaborolan-2-yl)­isophthalate (9.60 g, 30 mmol), and K2CO3 (13.82 g, 100 mmol) were added 1,4-dioxane (100 mL). After stirring, 0.50 g of Pd­(PPh3)2Cl2 (0.73 mmol) was added, and the reaction mixture was continuous stirred and refluxed at 85 °C for 3 days in an argon atmosphere. The resulting mixture was evaporated to dryness under reduced pressure, and the crude solid powder was purified through silica gel column chromatography employing the petroleum ether/ethyl acetate (v/v, 8/1) as eluent, so pure tetramethyl 2′-fluoro-[1,1′:4′,1′′-terphenyl]-3,3′′,5,5′′-tetracarboxylate (Me4TPTC, 4.20 g) is obtained. Yield: 66.8%. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3), δ = 8.72 (d, 2H), 8.48 (d, 4H), 7.62 (d, 1H), 7.58 (d, 1H), 7.52 (d, 1H), 3.99 (d, 12H) ppm.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the Organic Ligand H4FTPTC

To a mixture of 1,4-dibromo-2-fluorobenzene (2.54 g, 10 mmol), dimethyl 5-(4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-1,3,2-dioxaborolan-2-yl)isophthalate (9.60 g, 30 mmol), and K2CO3 (13.82 g, 100 mmol) were added 1,4-dioxane (100 mL). After stirring, 0.50 g of Pd(PPh3)2Cl2 (0.73 mmol) was added, and the reaction mixture was continuous stirred and refluxed at 85 °C for 3 days in an argon atmosphere. The resulting mixture was evaporated to dryness under reduced pressure, and the crude solid powder was purified through silica gel column chromatography employing the petroleum ether/ethyl acetate (v/v, 8/1) as eluent, so pure tetramethyl 2'-fluoro-[1,1':4',1''-terphenyl]-3,3'',5,5''-tetracarboxylate (Me4TPTC, 4.20 g) is obtained. Yield: 66.8%. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3), δ = 8.72 (d, 2H), 8.48 (d, 4H), 7.62 (d, 1H), 7.58 (d, 1H), 7.52 (d, 1H), 3.99 (d, 12H) ppm.

elements.content: To prepare the organic linker H4TPTC, Me4TPTC (3.21 g, 6.7 mmol) was first dispersed in a mixture of 10 mL of 1,4-dioxane solution and 50 mL of NaOH aqueous solution (3 M). The resulting mixture was then stirred and refluxed for 12 h. Concentrated HCl was used to acidify the clear solution until pH of the solution attains ∼3. The white powder was collected and washed with deionized water several times, then dried under vacuum to yield the H4TPTC (2.77 g, 97.8% yield). 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d 6), δ = 13.51 (s, 4H), 8.52 (d, 2H), 8.47 (s, 2H), 8.35 (s, 2H), 7.85 (d, 1H), 7.81 (t, 1H), 7.77 (d, 1H) ppm. 13C NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6), δ = 166.38, 166.32, 160.71, 158.25, 140.65, 140.57, 139.05, 135.23, 133.18, 132.39, 132.31, 131.96, 131.39, 131.36, 131.29, 129.45, 129.34, 126.05, 125.93, 123.61, 114.80, 114.56 ppm. Anal. Calcd for C22H13FO8: C, 62.27; H, 3.09. Found: C, 61.92; H, 3.47.
elements.clean_text: To prepare the organic linker H4TPTC, Me4TPTC (3.21 g, 6.7 mmol) was first dispersed in a mixture of 10 mL of 1,4-dioxane solution and 50 mL of NaOH aqueous solution (3 M). The resulting mixture was then stirred and refluxed for 12 h. Concentrated HCl was used to acidify the clear solution until pH of the solution attains ~3. The white powder was collected and washed with deionized water several times, then dried under vacuum to yield the H4TPTC (2.77 g, 97.8% yield). 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d 6), δ = 13.51 (s, 4H), 8.52 (d, 2H), 8.47 (s, 2H), 8.35 (s, 2H), 7.85 (d, 1H), 7.81 (t, 1H), 7.77 (d, 1H) ppm. 13C NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6), δ = 166.38, 166.32, 160.71, 158.25, 140.65, 140.57, 139.05, 135.23, 133.18, 132.39, 132.31, 131.96, 131.39, 131.36, 131.29, 129.45, 129.34, 126.05, 125.93, 123.61, 114.80, 114.56 ppm. Anal. Calcd for C22H13FO8: C, 62.27; H, 3.09. Found: C, 61.92; H, 3.47.

elements.content: Tb­(NO3)3·6­(H2O) (45.3 mg, 0.06 mmol), H4FTPTC (25.5 mg, 0.06 mmol), and 8 mL of DMF/H2O (v/v, 1:1) were mixed in a 15 mL screw-capped glass vial. After concentrated H2SO4 (18 M, 0.05 mL) was added, the glass vial was sealed and heated at 90 °C for 3 days. After filtration and washed with DMF, the colorless block crystal of TbFTPTC was obtained. Yield: 76%. Anal. Calcd for [Tb8(FTPTC)6·(DMF)8·(H2O)8]·(DMF)3.5·(H2O)12 (C166.5H174.5N11.5O81.5F6Tb8): C, 40.06; H, 3.62; N, 3.23. Found: C, 40.04; H, 3.52; N, 3.23. The EuFTPTC was prepared similarly as TbFTPTC, except that Eu­(NO3)3·6­(H2O) was used as the lanthanide salt.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Tb8(FTPTC)6⋅(DMF)8⋅(H2O)8]⋅(DMF)3.5⋅(H2O)12 (TbFTPTC) and EuFTPTC 

Tb(NO3)3⋅6(H2O) (45.3 mg, 0.06 mmol), H4FTPTC (25.5 mg, 0.06 mmol), and 8 mL of DMF/H2O (v/v, 1:1) were mixed in a 15 mL screw-capped glass vial. After concentrated H2SO4 (18 M, 0.05 mL) was added, the glass vial was sealed and heated at 90 °C for 3 days. After filtration and washed with DMF, the colorless block crystal of TbFTPTC was obtained. Yield: 76%. Anal. Calcd for [Tb8(FTPTC)6⋅(DMF)8⋅(H2O)8]⋅(DMF)3.5⋅(H2O)12 (C166.5H174.5N11.5O81.5F6Tb8): C, 40.06; H, 3.62; N, 3.23. Found: C, 40.04; H, 3.52; N, 3.23. The EuFTPTC was prepared similarly as TbFTPTC, except that Eu(NO3)3⋅6(H2O) was used as the lanthanide salt.

elements.content: The mixed LnMOF Tb 1–x Eu x FTPTC (x = 0.05, 0.10, 0.20) were prepared similarly to TbFTPTC except the Tb­(NO3)3·6­(H2O) was replaced by mixed lanthanide salts. The Tb3+/Eu3+ molar ratios in the as-prepared products Tb 1–x Eu x FTPTC was determined by ICP analysis (Table S2) and matched with the amounts of the corresponding salt used during the synthetic procedures.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of Tb1-x Eu x FTPTC 

The mixed LnMOF Tb  1-x   Eu   x   FTPTC (x = 0.05, 0.10, 0.20) were prepared similarly to TbFTPTC except the Tb(NO3)3⋅6(H2O) was replaced by mixed lanthanide salts. The Tb3+/Eu3+ molar ratios in the as-prepared products Tb  1-x   Eu    x    FTPTC was determined by ICP analysis (Table S2) and matched with the amounts of the corresponding salt used during the synthetic procedures.

elements.content: The organic ligand H4FTPTC was prepared by means of Suzuki coupling reaction, hydrolysis and acidification, as presented in Scheme S1. 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectroscopy were used to characterize the chemical structure of the ligand H4FTPTC. Solvothermal reaction of H4FTPTC with Tb­(NO3)3·6­(H2O) in mixed solvents of DMF, water, and sulfuric acid at 90 °C for 3 days yielded the colorless small block-like crystals of [Tb8(FTPTC)6·(DMF)8·(H2O)8]·(DMF)3.5·(H2O)12 (TbFTPTC). The formula of TbFTPTC was established by single-crystal XRD and elemental analysis, and the phase purity and thermostability of the synthesized bulk sample were investigated by PXRD and TGA data, respectively. Single-crystal XRD analysis shows that TbFTPTC crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/m, and manifests a three-dimensional (3D) structure constructed of double nuclear [Tb2(μ2-COO)4(COO)2] subunits. As shown in , two crystallographically independent eight-coordinated Tb atoms, at a spatial distance of 4.458 Å, are bridged by carbonyl units of FTPTC ligands to form the binuclear subunits [Tb2(μ2-COO)4(COO)2]. The coordination geometries of two Tb centers are very similar, delivering distorted tricapped trigonal prism (Figure S1a) with six carboxylate oxygen atoms from five FTPTC ligands and two oxygen atoms from terminal water or DMF molecules. The Tb–O bond lengths of TbFTPTC range from 2.264(6) to 2.564(6) Å, in accordance with the reported Tb-contained MOFs. The FTPTC ligands in the framework are coordinated with two different styles: μ8-coordination mode with four bridging bidentate carboxyl units and μ4-coordination mode with four chelating bidentate carboxyl units (Figure S1b). As shown in a, individual binuclear [Tb2(μ2-COO)4(COO)2] subunit is encircled by four FTPTC ligands with μ8-coordination style that connect the neighboring subunits into a 2D layer structure lying on the (100) plane, while the ligands with μ4-coordination style cross-link the 2D layers to construct a 3D framework delivering a 7.6 × 8.4 Å2 channel along the b-axis (b), and the overall network of this MOF can be determined as a 4,6-c net with the point symbol of {42;64}3{42;84}­{44;62}2{47;64;84}4 when the inorganic subunits and organic linker are regarded as 6-connected and 4-connected nodes. TbFTPTC, EuFTPTC, and mixed Tb 1–x Eu x FTPTC are isostructural, as confirmed by the similarity of their powder XRD patterns (Figure S2). The TGA curve of TbFTPTC indicates that the main crystal structure is thermally stable up to 310 °C (Figure S3), indicating its good thermostability.

Results and Discussion

The organic ligand H4FTPTC was prepared by means of Suzuki coupling reaction, hydrolysis and acidification, as presented in Scheme S1. 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectroscopy were used to characterize the chemical structure of the ligand H4FTPTC. Solvothermal reaction of H4FTPTC with Tb(NO3)3⋅6(H2O) in mixed solvents of DMF, water, and sulfuric acid at 90 °C for 3 days yielded the colorless small block-like crystals of [Tb8(FTPTC)6⋅(DMF)8⋅(H2O)8]⋅(DMF)3.5⋅(H2O)12 (TbFTPTC). The formula of TbFTPTC was established by single-crystal XRD and elemental analysis, and the phase purity and thermostability of the synthesized bulk sample were investigated by PXRD and TGA data, respectively. Single-crystal XRD analysis shows that TbFTPTC crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/m, and manifests a three-dimensional (3D) structure constructed of double nuclear [Tb2(μ2-COO)4(COO)2] subunits. As shown in , two crystallographically independent eight-coordinated Tb atoms, at a spatial distance of 4.458 Å, are bridged by carbonyl units of FTPTC ligands to form the binuclear subunits [Tb2(μ2-COO)4(COO)2]. The coordination geometries of two Tb centers are very similar, delivering distorted tricapped trigonal prism (Figure S1a) with six carboxylate oxygen atoms from five FTPTC ligands and two oxygen atoms from terminal water or DMF molecules. The Tb-O bond lengths of TbFTPTC range from 2.264(6) to 2.564(6) Å, in accordance with the reported Tb-contained MOFs. The FTPTC ligands in the framework are coordinated with two different styles: μ8-coordination mode with four bridging bidentate carboxyl units and μ4-coordination mode with four chelating bidentate carboxyl units (Figure S1b). As shown in a, individual binuclear [Tb2(μ2-COO)4(COO)2] subunit is encircled by four FTPTC ligands with μ8-coordination style that connect the neighboring subunits into a 2D layer structure lying on the (100) plane, while the ligands with μ4-coordination style cross-link the 2D layers to construct a 3D framework delivering a 7.6 × 8.4 Å2 channel along the b-axis (b), and the overall network of this MOF can be determined as a 4,6-c net with the point symbol of {42;64}3{42;84}{44;62}2{47;64;84}4 when the inorganic subunits and organic linker are regarded as 6-connected and 4-connected nodes. TbFTPTC, EuFTPTC, and mixed Tb  1-x   Eu   x   FTPTC are isostructural, as confirmed by the similarity of their powder XRD patterns (Figure S2). The TGA curve of TbFTPTC indicates that the main crystal structure is thermally stable up to 310 °C (Figure S3), indicating its good thermostability.

elements.content: To determine whether the H4PTPTC ligands can lead to efficient sensitization for the Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions, the luminescence spectra of the powder samples of the H4PTPTC and as-prepared MOFs were first investigated at room conditions. Under excitation at 350 nm, the ligand H4PTPTC displays a blue emission band centered at 415 nm which can be attributed to the singlet–singlet π–π* electronic transitions (Figure S4). Under excitation at 330 nm, the as-prepared MOFs display the typical lanthanide luminescence with well-defined emission bands (Figure S5 and S6). TbFTPTC exhibits the emission of 490, 543, 588, and 621 nm for the Tb3+ (5D4 → 7F6–3) transitions, while EuFTPTC displays emissions at 580, 592, 613, 653, and 703 nm which can be attributed to the 5D0 → 7F0–4 transitions of Eu3+ ion. As expected, all the mixed LnMOFs Tb 1–x Eu x FTPTC simultaneously exhibit both of the characteristic Tb3+ and Eu3+ emissions. Interestingly, the emission band of the H4FTPTC was not observed in all MOF samples, suggesting that the organic ligand H4FTPTC is a suitable chromophore for sensitizing the Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions. It is necessary to note that the luminescence of the Eu3+ in the mixed LnMOFs increased with the Eu3+ concentration, but that of the Tb3+ decreased. This can be attributed to the fact that the Eu3+ ions can be further sensitized by the Tb3+ with in the same framework via the metal-to-metal energy transfer mechanism, as well as the ligand H4FTPTC has a stronger antenna effect for Eu3+ ions compared to that of Tb3+ ions. A schematic overview of the energy transfer between the ligand H4FTPTC and lanthanide ions (Tb3+, Eu3+) for the mixed LnMOF is given in Figure S7. The lowest triplet excited state energy (T1) of the ligand H4FTPTC is determined to be 24037 cm–1 (Figure S8), which is located in the range of 22 000–27 000 cm–1 and matches the energy of the accepting level of Tb3+ (5D4, 20 500 cm–1) and Eu3+ (5D0, 17 200 cm–1) ions, thereby affording the efficient energy transfer from H4FTPTC to Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions. However, the energy difference between the H4FTPTC’s T1 and the 5D4 of Tb3+ is 3537 cm–1, which is much smaller compared to the difference between the H4FTPTC’s T1 and the 5D0 of Eu3+ (6837 cm–1). It means that at an elevated temperature the energy back-transfer from Tb3+ ions to H4FTPTC and the corresponding thermally driven quenches are much stronger than that of Eu3+. Accordingly, the sensitization of H4FTPTC to the luminescence of Eu3+ ions is more efficient, which is further confirmed by the quantum yield measurement. As listed in Table S3, the quantum yield of EuFTPTC is 20.40%, which is higher than that of TbFTPTC (14.11%), consistent with the previous analysis of the energy transfer processes. More importantly, due to the excellent antenna effect of H4FTPTC, all the mixed lanthanide Tb 0.95 Eu 0.05 FTPTC, Tb 0.90 Eu 0.10 FTPTC, and Tb 0.80 Eu 0.20 FTPTC exhibit a favorable quantum yield, suggesting that these lanthanide MOFs are excellent candidates for luminescent sensors. We note that although the emission intensity of Tb3+ is much lower compared with that of Eu3+ in the mixed lanthanide MOFs at room temperature it does not affect their application for use as ratiometric luminescent sensors at low temperatures since the Tb3+ emissions are significantly enhanced due to the depressed energy back-transfer and the nonradiative decays.

elements.content: The temperature dependence of the photoluminescence properties of the as-prepared mixed LnMOFs were characterized in terms of luminescence intensity and lifetime to assess their potential as the luminescent sensors for cryogenic temperatures. The temperature dependence of the luminescence spectra of TbFTPTC and EuFTPTC between 25 and 300 K is shown in Figure S9a,b, and the normalized intensities and lifetimes of Tb3+ at 543 nm (5D4 → 7F5) and Eu3+ at 613 nm (5D0 → 7F2) are displayed in Figure S9c,d. The luminescence intensities and lifetimes of both TbFTPTC and EuFTPTC decrease gradually with the temperature, presumably due to thermal activation of nonradiative decays. It should be pointed out that the decreased rate for 613 nm of TbFTPTC is much lower than that for 543 nm of EuFTPTC, which can be attributed to the fact that ligand has more efficient sensitization for Eu3+ ions, as has already been discussed. Compared with these two lanthanide MOFs, the mixed LnMOF Tb 0.95 Eu 0.05 FTPTC has a significantly different temperature dependence of luminescent behavior (a,b): The luminescent intensity of 613 nm (Eu3+, 5D0 → 7F2) increases as the temperature increases, but that of the 543 nm (Tb3+, 5D4 → 7F5) decreases. At 25 K, the emission band of 544 nm (Tb3+) is much stronger than that of 613 nm (Eu3+), whereas at 300 K the band of Eu3+ ion dominates the spectrum even though the Eu3+ concentration in the Tb 0.95 Eu 0.05 FTPTC is very low. Apparently, the luminescence behavior of the Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions within Tb 0.95 Eu 0.05 FTPTC is typical of Tb3+-to-Eu3+ energy transfer process, which can be enhanced via the thermally driven phonon-assisted energy transfer mechanism. In fact, similar luminescence behavior of the Tb3+ and Eu3+ were also observed in the other two mixed LnMOFs (Figures S10 and S11).

elements.content: In view of the different temperature responses of Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions in the mixed LnMOF Tb 0.95 Eu 0.05 FTPTC, the intensity ration of Tb3+ at 543 nm and Eu3+ at 613 nm can serve as a ratiometric parameter for self-calibrating temperature measurement. As depicted in c, the intensity ratio Δ (= I Tb/I Eu) of the Tb 0.95 Eu 0.05 FTPTC as a function of temperature (T) exhibits an excellent linear relationship in the cryogenic regime from 25 to 125 K that can be described as T = − 8.71232 Δ + 135.973 with the correlation coefficient of R 2 = 0.97. Therefore, this result suggests Tb 0.95 Eu 0.05 FTPTC is an excellent ratiometric thermometer that can be applied in the temperature range from 25 to 125 K. In addition, the powder XRD profiles of Tb 0.95 Eu 0.05 FTPTC do not change after cryogenic photoluminescence measurements and for three months under room conditions (Figure S12), suggesting favorable stability of Tb 0.95 Eu 0.05 FTPTC, as well as highlighting its great potential for application in cryogenic temperature sensing. The temperature-dependent luminescent properties of Tb 0.90 Eu 0.10 FTPTC and Tb 0.80 Eu 0.20 FTPTC were also investigated to assess the effects of the molar ratio of Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions in the mixed LnMOFs. As displayed in Figure S13, the intensity ratios of the two mixed LnMOFs were also readily correlated to the temperature and show linear relationships in the range from 25 to 125 K. Such a result suggests that the simple control of the molar ratio of the Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions in the same framework cannot modulate the temperature operating range of the MOFs Tb 1–x Eu x FTPTC, which is consistent with our previous studies.

elements.content: The different luminescence colors and temperature-dependent behaviors of Tb3+ and Eu3+ within these mixed LnMOFs have enabled them to directly visualize temperature variation instantly and intuitively; we thus examine the Tb 0.95 Eu 0.05 FTPTC in detail. As shown in , the luminescence color of the Tb 0.95 Eu 0.05 FTPTC is systematically changed from the green to yellow-green in the operating cryogenic range of 25–125 K, which can be easily observed by the naked eyes, PMTs, and CCDs. In addition, the corresponding color coordinates (x, y) change from (0.3255, 0.5912) at 25 K to (0.4351, 0.5095) at 125 K.

elements.content: The relative sensitivity (S r), as an index to assess the performance of ratiometric luminescent thermometers, can be determined as S r = ∂ Δ / ∂ T Δ where Δ represents the intensity ratio of Tb3+ and Eu3+ emissions and T represents the corresponding temperature. By this definition, the relative sensitivity of Tb 0.95 Eu 0.05 FTPTC is calculated to be 0.91%·K–1 at 25 K, then increase to 9.11%·K–1 at 125 K (Figure S14), which is comparable with that of many reported luminescent MOF sensors in cryogenic temperatures (Table S4). Clearly, the gradual improvement of the relative sensitivity is due to the large decrease of Tb3+ emission and increase of Eu3+ emission in Tb 0.95 Eu 0.05 FTPTC. Similar results also can be observed in other two mixed lanthanide MOFs. As shown in Figure S15, the relative sensitivity range of Tb 0.90 Eu 0.10 FTPTC and Tb 0.80 Eu 0.20 FTPTC is from 1.29 to 36.90%·K–1 and from 0.93 to 12.94%·K–1, respectively, suggesting the two materials are also promising candidates for luminescent sensors for cryogenic temperature measurement. Importantly, the different sensitivities ranges of the three mixed lanthanide MOFs Tb 1–x Eu x FTPTC also indicate the sensitivity can be tuned by changing the molar ratio of Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions in the same framework.

elements.content: The high and tunable temperature sensitivity of Tb 1–x Eu x FTPTC is associated with the different temperature-dependent luminescence behaviors of Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions, which can be attributed to the different temperature dependence of energy transfer probabilities from the Tb3+ to Eu3+ ions in Tb 1–x Eu x FTPTC. a shows that Tb 0.95 Eu 0.05 FTPTC has a shorter 5D4 (543 nm) lifetime than that of TbFTPTC but a longer 5D0 (613 nm) lifetime than that of EuFTPTC in the temperature range of 25–300 K. Moreover, the fluorescence lifetime of 5D4 in Tb 0.95 Eu 0.05 FTPTC decrease dramatically from 1014 μs at 25 K to 33.87 μs at 300 K, whereas the lifetime of 5D0 decrease very slowly from 1168 μs at 25 K to 940.5 μs at 300 K. These results suggest that energy transfer from Tb3+ to Eu3+ ions takes place in Tb 0.95 Eu 0.05 FTPTC as the temperature is increased. Similar results also can be observed in other two MOFs, Tb 0.90 Eu 0.10 FTPTC and Tb 0.80 Eu 0.20 FTPTC (Figure S16).

elements.content: The efficiency (η) of the Tb3+-to-Eu3+ energy transfer is given by η = 1 − τ d τ where τ and τd are the 5D4 lifetimes of Tb3+ ions in TbFTPTC and Tb 1–x Eu x FTPTC, respectively. The obtained energy transfer efficiency of Tb3+-to-Eu3+ in Tb 1–x Eu x FTPTC exhibits substantially increases at the elevated temperature (Figure S17), leading to the enhancement of the Eu3+ emission at the expense of quenching the Tb3+ emission, which is mainly governed by thermally driven phonon-assisted energy transfer mechanism. Among the three MOFs, Tb 0.95 Eu 0.05 FTPTC has the lowest Eu3+ content and shows the lowest energy transfer efficiency of about 6.67% at 25 K, then increase to 43.72% at 125 K (b). Importantly, with increasing Eu3+, the energy transfer efficiency is significantly increased at the same temperature, indicating that the energy transfer efficiency from Tb3+ to Eu3+ of Tb 1–x Eu x FTPTC in the operating range of 25–125 K can be tuned by increasing the Eu3+ concentration, a useful approach that can guide the design of luminescent mixed LnMOF thermometers for cryogenic temperature sensing.

elements.content: A fluorine-modified organic linker 2′-fluoro-[1,1′:4′,1′′-terphenyl]-3,3′′,5,5′′-tetracarboxylic acid was synthesized and used for constructing the luminescent mixed lanthanide MOFs Tb 1–x Eu x FTPTC, since its lowest triplet energy (23407 cm–1) can effectively sensitize Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions to form a dual-emitting system for self-calibrating temperature measurement. The potential application of Tb 1–x Eu x FTPTC as self-calibrating luminescent thermometers for cryogenic temperatures was discussed in terms of the luminescence intensity and lifetime. All three mixed lanthanide MOFs exhibit distinctly linear response to temperature in the cryogenic regime of 25 to 125 K and favorable relative sensitivities. More importantly, the relative sensitivity of such mixed lanthanide MOFs can readily be tuned by adjusting the incorporation amount of Eu3+ ions in the host framework. The richness of organic ligands with suitable triplet energy and lanthanides provides nearly limitless choices for constructing different types of luminescent MOF thermometers, whose two luminescence centers can be elaborately designed to optimized the sensing range and sensitivity of the thermometers. Our results therefore provide a guide for designing novel mixed lanthanide MOFs with tunable relative sensitivity and should induce further research on lanthanide MOFs for accurate temperature sensing in the cryogenic regime.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A fluorine-modified organic linker 2'-fluoro-[1,1':4',1''-terphenyl]-3,3'',5,5''-tetracarboxylic acid was synthesized and used for constructing the luminescent mixed lanthanide MOFs Tb  1-x   Eu   x   FTPTC, since its lowest triplet energy (23407 cm-1) can effectively sensitize Tb3+ and Eu3+ ions to form a dual-emitting system for self-calibrating temperature measurement. The potential application of Tb  1-x   Eu   x   FTPTC as self-calibrating luminescent thermometers for cryogenic temperatures was discussed in terms of the luminescence intensity and lifetime. All three mixed lanthanide MOFs exhibit distinctly linear response to temperature in the cryogenic regime of 25 to 125 K and favorable relative sensitivities. More importantly, the relative sensitivity of such mixed lanthanide MOFs can readily be tuned by adjusting the incorporation amount of Eu3+ ions in the host framework. The richness of organic ligands with suitable triplet energy and lanthanides provides nearly limitless choices for constructing different types of luminescent MOF thermometers, whose two luminescence centers can be elaborately designed to optimized the sensing range and sensitivity of the thermometers. Our results therefore provide a guide for designing novel mixed lanthanide MOFs with tunable relative sensitivity and should induce further research on lanthanide MOFs for accurate temperature sensing in the cryogenic regime.

cln_elements.content:
To a mixture of 1,4-dibromo-2-fluorobenzene (2.54 g, 10 mmol), dimethyl 5-(4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-1,3,2-dioxaborolan-2-yl)­isophthalate (9.60 g, 30 mmol), and K2CO3 (13.82 g, 100 mmol) were added 1,4-dioxane (100 mL). After stirring, 0.50 g of Pd­(PPh3)2Cl2 (0.73 mmol) was added, and the reaction mixture was continuous stirred and refluxed at 85 °C for 3 days in an argon atmosphere. The resulting mixture was evaporated to dryness under reduced pressure, and the crude solid powder was purified through silica gel column chromatography employing the petroleum ether/ethyl acetate (v/v, 8/1) as eluent, so pure tetramethyl 2′-fluoro-[1,1′:4′,1′′-terphenyl]-3,3′′,5,5′′-tetracarboxylate (Me4TPTC, 4.20 g) is obtained. Yield: 66.8%. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3), δ = 8.72 (d, 2H), 8.48 (d, 4H), 7.62 (d, 1H), 7.58 (d, 1H), 7.52 (d, 1H), 3.99 (d, 12H) ppm.

To prepare the organic linker H4TPTC, Me4TPTC (3.21 g, 6.7 mmol) was first dispersed in a mixture of 10 mL of 1,4-dioxane solution and 50 mL of NaOH aqueous solution (3 M). The resulting mixture was then stirred and refluxed for 12 h. Concentrated HCl was used to acidify the clear solution until pH of the solution attains ∼3. The white powder was collected and washed with deionized water several times, then dried under vacuum to yield the H4TPTC (2.77 g, 97.8% yield). 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d 6), δ = 13.51 (s, 4H), 8.52 (d, 2H), 8.47 (s, 2H), 8.35 (s, 2H), 7.85 (d, 1H), 7.81 (t, 1H), 7.77 (d, 1H) ppm. 13C NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6), δ = 166.38, 166.32, 160.71, 158.25, 140.65, 140.57, 139.05, 135.23, 133.18, 132.39, 132.31, 131.96, 131.39, 131.36, 131.29, 129.45, 129.34, 126.05, 125.93, 123.61, 114.80, 114.56 ppm. Anal. Calcd for C22H13FO8: C, 62.27; H, 3.09. Found: C, 61.92; H, 3.47.

Synthesis of [Tb<sub>8</sub>(FTPTC)<sub>6</sub>·(DMF)<sub>8</sub>·(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>8</sub>]·(DMF)<sub>3.5</sub>·(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>12</sub> (<bold>TbFTPTC</bold>) and <bold>EuFTPTC</bold>

Tb­(NO3)3·6­(H2O) (45.3 mg, 0.06 mmol), H4FTPTC (25.5 mg, 0.06 mmol), and 8 mL of DMF/H2O (v/v, 1:1) were mixed in a 15 mL screw-capped glass vial. After concentrated H2SO4 (18 M, 0.05 mL) was added, the glass vial was sealed and heated at 90 °C for 3 days. After filtration and washed with DMF, the colorless block crystal of TbFTPTC was obtained. Yield: 76%. Anal. Calcd for [Tb8(FTPTC)6·(DMF)8·(H2O)8]·(DMF)3.5·(H2O)12 (C166.5H174.5N11.5O81.5F6Tb8): C, 40.06; H, 3.62; N, 3.23. Found: C, 40.04; H, 3.52; N, 3.23. The EuFTPTC was prepared similarly as TbFTPTC, except that Eu­(NO3)3·6­(H2O) was used as the lanthanide salt.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the Organic Ligand H4FTPTC

To a mixture of 1,4-dibromo-2-fluorobenzene (2.54 g, 10 mmol), dimethyl 5-(4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-1,3,2-dioxaborolan-2-yl)isophthalate (9.60 g, 30 mmol), and K2CO3 (13.82 g, 100 mmol) were added 1,4-dioxane (100 mL). After stirring, 0.50 g of Pd(PPh3)2Cl2 (0.73 mmol) was added, and the reaction mixture was continuous stirred and refluxed at 85 °C for 3 days in an argon atmosphere. The resulting mixture was evaporated to dryness under reduced pressure, and the crude solid powder was purified through silica gel column chromatography employing the petroleum ether/ethyl acetate (v/v, 8/1) as eluent, so pure tetramethyl 2'-fluoro-[1,1':4',1''-terphenyl]-3,3'',5,5''-tetracarboxylate (Me4TPTC, 4.20 g) is obtained. Yield: 66.8%. 1H NMR (500 MHz, CDCl3), δ = 8.72 (d, 2H), 8.48 (d, 4H), 7.62 (d, 1H), 7.58 (d, 1H), 7.52 (d, 1H), 3.99 (d, 12H) ppm.

To prepare the organic linker H4TPTC, Me4TPTC (3.21 g, 6.7 mmol) was first dispersed in a mixture of 10 mL of 1,4-dioxane solution and 50 mL of NaOH aqueous solution (3 M). The resulting mixture was then stirred and refluxed for 12 h. Concentrated HCl was used to acidify the clear solution until pH of the solution attains ~3. The white powder was collected and washed with deionized water several times, then dried under vacuum to yield the H4TPTC (2.77 g, 97.8% yield). 1H NMR (500 MHz, DMSO-d 6), δ = 13.51 (s, 4H), 8.52 (d, 2H), 8.47 (s, 2H), 8.35 (s, 2H), 7.85 (d, 1H), 7.81 (t, 1H), 7.77 (d, 1H) ppm. 13C NMR (400 MHz, DMSO-d 6), δ = 166.38, 166.32, 160.71, 158.25, 140.65, 140.57, 139.05, 135.23, 133.18, 132.39, 132.31, 131.96, 131.39, 131.36, 131.29, 129.45, 129.34, 126.05, 125.93, 123.61, 114.80, 114.56 ppm. Anal. Calcd for C22H13FO8: C, 62.27; H, 3.09. Found: C, 61.92; H, 3.47.

Synthesis of [Tb8(FTPTC)6⋅(DMF)8⋅(H2O)8]⋅(DMF)3.5⋅(H2O)12 (TbFTPTC) and EuFTPTC 

Tb(NO3)3⋅6(H2O) (45.3 mg, 0.06 mmol), H4FTPTC (25.5 mg, 0.06 mmol), and 8 mL of DMF/H2O (v/v, 1:1) were mixed in a 15 mL screw-capped glass vial. After concentrated H2SO4 (18 M, 0.05 mL) was added, the glass vial was sealed and heated at 90 °C for 3 days. After filtration and washed with DMF, the colorless block crystal of TbFTPTC was obtained. Yield: 76%. Anal. Calcd for [Tb8(FTPTC)6⋅(DMF)8⋅(H2O)8]⋅(DMF)3.5⋅(H2O)12 (C166.5H174.5N11.5O81.5F6Tb8): C, 40.06; H, 3.62; N, 3.23. Found: C, 40.04; H, 3.52; N, 3.23. The EuFTPTC was prepared similarly as TbFTPTC, except that Eu(NO3)3⋅6(H2O) was used as the lanthanide salt.
